This study aims to improve the temporal resolution of radar rainfall products to enhance accurate climate change modeling and studies. To achieve this, we introduce EfficientTempNet, a solution based on EfficientNetV2, to increase the temporal resolution of radar-based rainfall products from 10 minutes to 5 minutes. We tested EfficientTempNet on a dataset for the state of Iowa, US, and compared its performance to three different baselines to demonstrate its viability for better climate change monitoring.

The importance of environmental data has grown significantly in recent years due to the increased impact of natural disasters. Rainfall data plays a crucial role in various climate modeling applications, such as flood forecasting, monitoring water quality, and managing wastewater. Reliable and accessible precipitation maps are vital for advancing research on climate-related hazards, including risk assessment and disaster mitigation. Quantitative Precipitation Estimation (QPE) systems provide rainfall data with three dimensions: latitude, longitude, and temporal resolution. Weather radars are the primary source used in QPE, allowing for the recording of space-time characteristics of precipitation, essential for accurate streamflow predictions in hydrology. Improving rainfall datasets in radar hydrology involves addressing uncertainty factors and acquiring more precise precipitation data to enhance our understanding of weather patterns in space and time.

The temporal resolution of rainfall data is a critical factor in determining the accuracy of predictive modeling efforts. This paper aims to address the issue of low temporal resolution rainfall products by proposing a convolutional neural network to enhance the temporal resolution of rainfall data. The proposed CNN model, EfficientTempNet, is based on EfficientNetV2, and its performance is compared to three different methods: the nearest frame, optical flow, and TempNet.

Rainfall products are not the only data subject to temporal interpolation between two 2D maps. Various studies in computer vision literature have employed neural networks-based approaches for video frame interpolation. However, the literature on interpolating time in rainfall datasets is limited. A previous study used advection correction to create 1-minute rainfall maps from 5-minute ones. Building upon this, a residual CNN architecture, TempNet, was proposed and shown to be superior to other methods over the IowaRain dataset. To the best of our knowledge, TempNet is the only study that tackles the problem of temporal super-resolution of radar rainfall products using neural networks, forming the baseline of this study.

The paper is organized as follows: Section 2 introduces the dataset used and provides an overview of the methodology. Section 3 presents and discusses the preliminary results of the comparison between all methods. Finally, Section 4 summarizes the findings.

The IowaRain dataset covers the years 2016 and 2019 with 5-minute temporal resolution, covering an area that bounds the state of Iowa. To address memory bottlenecks and computational complexity, we sampled an area within the IowaRain domain from eastern Iowa, downscaled the rainmap spatial resolution to 3 km, and applied the event detection criteria to obtain 82, 83, 90, and 110 events for each year.
